To The Editor Of the ITimington,an.


In your last Number, an additional io7p

tossum memory. That shameful production,
fraucht with the most glaring falsehoods, is

anv Trustees, and which, as member,
much regret.


have turned those "Trustces" over to
the legal authority who have no doubt will
duly appreciate their wants, and do them
that Justice their infamous deeds deserve.


MY statement, by way of reply, in your
former paper, is substantially correct; and
have been, and am ready and willingto settle
on Just and equitable terms with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid Of
principle, but | never can condescend to
men 50 destitute of every principle that cha
racterizes the individuals who have so wan
tonly assailed my character


With respect to the certificate of Patrick,
it is bundle of absurdities worthy the au-
thor. He says he has known me for TWEEN
ty-ive wears, (it is true, and the only truth
lC HAS daotliNNsJs w ifi7 h'c"' ~ Nt'N' a
have well known him to my sorrow. he can
advert to the time and we'll remember, who
! first started him in I Thoroughfare Neck, and

without friends, or money to pay his debts or
1 subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gaze him employ when not worth penny

rick 10 sting the hand of his bentauor, sad
der like" that hand which nourished and
sust inpd hin.e


Next, it, order, would notice the knight
of the Bolus whose stupidity is only equalet
by his impudence in bringing into view the
name Of my friend of the city of Lancaster
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was ran OF reputation" and had drcoyet
to his residence; which, when by me dis.
cerncd, for the safety of his character anc
person ccAed for, considering him unsat,
in tho company of such "rehtite."


now take leave of the Trustees Of St
Peters Church" patrick, and his quan


dam friend, the Qnack, intending on no fu
ture occasion to notice their nefarious pro


ductions.


VIM. LARKIN.

We now challenge you to come before any three

you are; so that we shall prevent you from

MISCELLANEOUS.

Mr.. Billy Iarkn why are you barking at me J
We never had the change OF an unpleasant word.
| know of no cause of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting p,y refusing you to put my shout
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
oftruth. showed it to Mr. Wales, who is one
of the four law agents employed against you.-
Do you state there is no suit against you but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr.. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intruded yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. Keenan, say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that Mr.. Keenan is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster,
so see that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defamations
to be published, that your attack OIL me must
be founded on envy and falschood as the public
know that advertise in this Borough in TIVE
newspapers to let every one in the Unitod
States know who am, what am, and where 7
am, SO that you are, to make the most of Won.
bad minded man. The principle cause. I be.
heve, OF your behaviour, is my sending Won bact


a pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted n


quarter of pound of the weight. done So to
prevent your doing so again--you, in an nsolen,
manner, told the woman that your wepbts were
as honest as mine. But this would not do vo,,r
son had to give hera pound of candles as she
pad you tor them. This is one ofthe causcs ~
your savage lying, and vndctve malice. ''' u

little; the third year cut them off about io
inches from the ground, in March; the fourth
year cut them from two or three feet high
taking away all but one branch from each
vine, for tralings to make the new rows, or
for cuttings to set elsewhere. Some OF the
vines bore grapes the third year, on the
shoots which grew the second year, (as 1t IS
always on the last years. shoots, the grapes
are borne, after which these shoots, which
have borne, are taken away, and the shoots
Of the preceding year left to bear, by being
cut from three to four feet high, tying them
to a prop or stake. When the young clust-
ers appear, pinch off the shoot above the
second cluster, and also the buds or sprouts
which put out at the but-end Of the stem OF
the leaves. which sprouts would form limbs
or branches that would cucumber the clus-
t-rs, and rob them too much Of the benefit OF
the sun and air. and also draw away TOO
much ofthe sap of the vine from the grapes,
and thus prevent them from coming to per-
fection.


GATHERING.
cut the clusters Oft, and carry them TO
the press. The epoch OF maturity is about
the first of October mash them (the
grapes)wel. and then press them like Cider
&c. &c. &c.





EXPENSES.
I calculate it cost me seventy live dollars
per acre to plant and attend to the vines,
until they began the third year to bear.


QUANTITY.


In four acres, about one fourth bore grapes
the third year, and made about three bar
rels of wine; the fourth year made thirteen
barrels; tie mn gear M,rty-one barrels,
| (fifteen and half hogsheads.) But must
observe, that many of the vines were young,
as yook away many that were not OF a
good sort, and replaced them, and the first
vines were two years old, and in some places
three, before they were sufficiently long to
trail, and form the Intermediate rows; sc
that, in the fifth year, some were but two
and some three years old, of course not in a
bearing conditiop. ! think | NAV safely
say not more than half were i'll a bearing
conditions


PRICE.


We got for the first wine, four dollars
fer gallon. .dtferuards 7ee sold a. three
and gve are noqu selling al taro doIlars IN
gallon.


CUTTINGS.


The last season we sold l4,0O0, abou
four feet long. at thirty dollars per thousand
420 dollars.


Yours. &c.

CULTIVATION OF THE VINE
The National Intelligencer of "Wednesday /
contains well written communication from
a Mr.. Album, on the culture of the Vine
AS we shall eventually make our own wines
in this country,-the sooner the better,-we
have thought it would be interesting to our
readers to learn how profitable this business
may be made by those possessing enter
prise, industry, and the resolution to conquer
their attachment to old habits


The writer commences with remarks on
the cultivation Of the vine in France, and
with sundry statements exhibiting the an
nual expense of cultivating an acre of vines
in various parts of Europe, the quantity OF
wine produced, and the nett produce per
acre. He remarks that four acres of vine
are sufficient in France to occupy one labor
err and thinks that an American laborcr
will perform twice the quantity that a
French peasant will. An acre of vines netts
in Provence, $40 IS; Guinenne, 3 IS; the
Lyonnais, 26 73; Nivornois, IS 10; in the
different departments of Burgundy, from 8
13 to % so; Sologne 6 27; Seine l8 36;
Champagne, 6 16 Hevouches Chaptal for
the accuracy of these statements.


"Ten acres of the vines i'll France pro-
duced ninety hogsheads of SO gallons each,
valued at 1854 e3; the expense of cutivat
ing those ten acres amounts to $3.50 7e; an
interest of ten per centum on those expenses
amounts to S35 81; and the indemnity
of from eight to ten per cent. for loss of
crops amounts to $50 SO, leaving nett prof
it on the 10 acres, OF Sl38 ID, or 13 81 for
each acre.


A small compensation, though double the
nett profit of an acre of corn or wheat in the
United States in ordinary times. In France
the acre of vine is considered more pro-
ductive than an acre of wheat.


Yhe article closes with the following Just
views of the profits of Vineyard, conduct
ed with skill and industry. One thing we
may observe that the culture of the vine
promises as great prosperity III Pennsy ylvania
as in Virginia.


1t appears to us, no sugar or cotton plan,
tc.tion, in their best and most hourishing pc
riods; no species of agriculture, in the best
soils, or horticulture in rich gardens in the
vicinity of large city markets. ever produced
Iuch profits as the vine would yield for a CEN
fury to come if properly cultivated in the U,
States.


The heavy impost on foreign wines, oper-
ates not only as a protecting duty, but as a
prodigious bounty.


If young proprietor, who has just come
60 his estate, in that beautiful section of our
country. would set seriously to work in
planting the vine, before he arrives at the
middle age of man, he would inevitably be-
come the richest planter in the state.


Of the old planter, we cannot expec,
much reformation, for


"Habits are stubborn things;


And when man is turned of forty,


The ruling PASSIONS grown SO naughty,


There's no clipping of its wings


He offers very satisfactory statement o
the cost of vineyard of ten acres, making
1t amount on the fifth year of its culture
Ithe epoch of its full bearing) to 2,o25 dol
lars. Then follows a statement of gros
produce-annual advances for cultivation
and nett products Of an American Vineyard
Of ten acres.


This, it must be remembered, is not
mere creature of pen, ink, and paper but il
substantially that made by Mr.. Eichelberge
Of York, in Pennsylvania, who has devot
ed much time to the consideration of this sub
ject


Produce of ten acres.


so hhds. $3.50 gals. at doll. S3,79o 0


Deduct,


Annual advances per acre.


as dollars $3.50


Ten per cent interest there


on, 95


len per cent indemnity on


gross produce for loss of


crops 378

Or S312 20 per acre.


A result which, we trust, offers suffi
cient encouragement to every reasonabl
proprietor of the soil 10 commence the ereo
THE FARMDR.

From the Philadelphia Palladium.
CULTIVATION OF THE VINE.

York. Penn. June 4, 1924.
Dear Sir--Yours of 5th ult came safe to
hand, and my being somewhat unwell must
be an apology for my not replying sooner.
Twill now attempt it, and to your first ques-
fion:


SOIL.


Mine is slaty ridge. in a limestone
country, and presume there is limestone
under it.


PLANTING.


Iplanted my vines in rows, by digging a
french four feet long, and about nine inches
wide, and fifteen inches deep. In this plant
cd, at each end, two cuttings, about three
and half or four feet long, letting two buds
appear on each vine above ground, then l
filled up the trench, packing the ground
pretty tight; then, four feet from the end OF
this trench. dug another similar, and plant
ed 1t in the same way, and so OH until the
row was finished. BY this mode the vines
are two in place, and each two, four feet
from the next in the row. The next row
planted twelve feet from the first, in the
same way. The second and third years,
when the shoots were long enough, dug a
trench crossways, from each row, four feet
long, towards the opposite row, and laid
the branches or shoots from the first plant
ed rows, IN them, letting the ends of the
two vines be little above ground; by this
means two rows in the twelve feet interval
are formed, which makes all the rows four
feet apart.


PRUNING.


The first year none; the second year very
YORK, Penn. June 4. 1924.

sold the two classes FOR, as you could not get
more shan 500 dollars for each class. where
then did the Cos dollars come from over the
price of the two classcs' so that one might tninK
you wronged Hope, or made sham sale OF the
lottery, with an intent to defraud the church,
All, Mr.. Billy, we have documents from Thomas
Hopes hand, which firmly prove that the
nett profits on the first class, after paying the
prizes, amc lnted to 1896 dollars; and that the
profits on the second class amounted to 4765 dol
lars. What an unfortunate business for you!-A
You say the third class was managed by Patrick
Higgins-the following will say to the contrary;


Statement of Patrick Higgins.


81 shall state, as one Of the four managers OF
the Lottery, sold by William Larkin, principal
manager and treasurer, who received the pro-
ceeds of the four classes of the Delaware Lotte-
nv, intended by the Legislature of this State for
the use and benefit of st. Peters Church IN TINS
Borough, that after the first and second class
cs were drawn, VIM I.arlSin requested me to
take the management of the Sd class, as he said
he was fatigued. | told him l would do any
thing in my power to assist the Church. He
gave me the tickets, and some time after he
came to me, with Arthur Murphy, and said he
would not sign the tickets unless Murphy and
would give him a bill of indemnity, that in case
of loss in the third class we should suffer like.
AS
Lottery schemes than an old woman, we signed
the bond. | now inform the public, that Will
liam Larkin, sometime after this, pursuadcd poor
Murphy to Join with him and N. G. williamson,
and form Board of Managers, and take the
| Lottery from me; which they did and Larkn
and Tho's. Hope sold it between them Alter
they took the third class from me, Larkin sent
his order to me to give Thomas Hope one thou
sand tickets, which order hold to tins day
Altho' he states in the paper that 1t was under
nv care the third class was sold. l have Lar
kn's order and Hopes receipt for every ticket
he got from me. This is the rich harvest thot
to save, which Larkin acknowledges 10 have dis.
appointed me in. He states the Sd class was all
under my care, which is false, as have his own
order to prove it so. This order and all the do
cuments relative to the Lottery, gave to Doc
tor Purcell by order of the rrustees SO that, Lar
kin, every statement YOU made in the Whining
tonian is false, and i inform the public that
know you these twenty-five years, and that
have document relating to you, to prove wha'
| say to be true.


Iarkin calls us sclf-created trustees-yoI
seem to forget the 18th Of April 1924, when W.
were the trustees, whom with the late and mucl
to he regretted Victor Du Pont, rejected YOU





Treasurer ora Trustee ever since in the Church
The last day We met you was in Doctor PercclP'
shop, where you began your old trade of black
guaring us. You know you promised thai
day, which was the Esd of January last, to bring
up your books, ard appointed the Doctor to set
tie with the church on your part, and we ap


pointed the late and revcred Victor Du Pont OF


Our part; which you agreed to: after, VIC saw


Mr.. Du Pont he said if you would carry up You


books to Doctor Purcell to be examined, and i


the doctor could do any thing with the books re


specting settlement, Mr.. Du Pont would call OF


the Doctor on Saturday aiter,to consult with him
if they could arrange settlement We return


ed to William I.arkin and informed him Of wlli


Mr.. Du Pont said to us-4.arkin's answer to Il
was, he had no books, and would settle no &C


counts. See this unprincipled man-cqually re
gardlcss Of his solemn promise, or of committing
sacrllegc. His actions are the surest standarI
to Judge him by. After the Lottery was draw
in January, 1924, we, the trustees of st. Peter
Church, insisted on settlement from I.arkln -

full articles.article:
To The Editor Of the ITimington,an.


In your last Number, an additional io7p
and scurrilous publication has appeared a.
gaiust me from the famous would-be Irus-
tees Of St. Peters Church, backed by the
certificate of Patrick Higgins, and the after
piece of the notorious Quack Doctor, of OH
tossum memory. That shameful production,
fraucht with the most glaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character of
anv Trustees, and which, as member,
much regret.


have turned those "Trustces" over to
the legal authority who have no doubt will
duly appreciate their wants, and do them
that Justice their infamous deeds deserve.


MY statement, by way of reply, in your
former paper, is substantially correct; and
have been, and am ready and willingto settle
on Just and equitable terms with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid Of
principle, but | never can condescend to
men 50 destitute of every principle that cha
racterizes the individuals who have so wan
tonly assailed my character


With respect to the certificate of Patrick,
it is bundle of absurdities worthy the au-
thor. He says he has known me for TWEEN
ty-ive wears, (it is true, and the only truth
lC HAS daotliNNsJs w ifi7 h'c"' ~ Nt'N' a
have well known him to my sorrow. he can
advert to the time and we'll remember, who
! first started him in I Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it WAS that Was the loser thereby byhia T-
rrpuiar zvayS, and who afterwards helped
/ him back to Wilmington, and aided him when
without friends, or money to pay his debts or
1 subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gaze him employ when not worth penny
| Ask aud reflect. DOES it argue well for Pat
rick 10 sting the hand of his bentauor, sad
der like" that hand which nourished and
sust inpd hin.e


Next, it, order, would notice the knight
of the Bolus whose stupidity is only equalet
by his impudence in bringing into view the
name Of my friend of the city of Lancaster
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was ran OF reputation" and had drcoyet
to his residence; which, when by me dis.
cerncd, for the safety of his character anc
person ccAed for, considering him unsat,
in tho company of such "rehtite."


now take leave of the Trustees Of St
Peters Church" patrick, and his quan


dam friend, the Qnack, intending on no fu
ture occasion to notice their nefarious pro


ductions.


VIM. LARKIN.


Wilmington, March z, 18c7.-25--4t.

WE, the trustees of st. Peters Church in the


Borough of Wilmington, State of Delaware, see


ng an appeal to the public by william LarkIn,
wherein he charges ,is, Peter Fierce, BERNARD
MCann, Bernard M'Guigen, and John Durnn


With uniIstly assang, and most wantony Sian
dcrng the said Vim. l.arkln's character. He
then proceeds to say he feels it duty he owes
to himself and his friends to rcpcl the unauthor-
izcd, base and ,lnfonudcd charges made by those
caiumniators, and expose them to that contempt
they merit. lie then comes forward, honest
man like, to exhibit 10 public view a statement of
the facts connected with the lottery case alluded
to: he rcqu, SIS the public TO recollect the pc
riol the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922


for raising the sum of 5000 dollars for the use of
81 Peters Church and payment of debts, over all
expenses he then states the managers Of the
lottery then agreed that one of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the przes--this was the most substantial part of
the business, although poor BILLY says it was un-


ortunatc for him, or as the selfcrcated trustees


would have il, it was unfortunate for the Church


the trustees are a get of impudent fellows, for
not pitying poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses of the church; poor Billy goes on to in.
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
| Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and


after the sale the first and second classes, hon
SoA biHN " TO VIC l'uJttS WITH HuSt DtlC-
faced falschood, that he paid the church, i'll cash
and note, and payment ofdebts, the full amount
and upwards, say 1905 dollars. AS he treats the
public opinion with the same insolence as he has
treated the congregation Of ST. Peters Church,


We now challenge you to come before any three
or more respectable men Of the Borough and we
are ready to meet any hour you appoint, face to
face, and if you can produce one solitary docu-
ment of receipt or settlement for any sum OF
money, even for one dollar, since the commence
ment of the drawing of the lottery until this
day. we shall acknowledge your assertion to be
true, and you cannot produce any receipt oil
settlement from he trustees of St. Peters
Church you must be the most abandoned crea
ture upon earth--we challenge you to produce il


in fory-eght hours, or you stand convicted, a.
you are; so that we shall prevent you from


imposing any longer on the public. Our for


bearancc for SO long a time with you, was from


motives Of charity, not wishing to injurc YOU


character, as VIC would do, for any man in busi
ness; but we see you are the same obduratt


and perverted wretch still, after all our indul


gence to you. We point out an Infamous false


hood on the face of the document you have Sc
/ before the public, where you say you sold 81,
, classes Of the lottery to Thomas Hope for 50t
dollars each, to be paid by Hope as each clas


was sold. You state that after the lst and I'd class
es were sold, you paid the church the sum o
, 1905 dollars in cash and note. You could not pa,
out Of one thousand dollars, which you state yo'

full articles.headline: March /, 1897
full articles.article:
Mr.. Billy Iarkn why are you barking at me J
We never had the change OF an unpleasant word.
| know of no cause of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting p,y refusing you to put my shout
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which you called your accompt current,
without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
oftruth. showed it to Mr. Wales, who is one
of the four law agents employed against you.-
Do you state there is no suit against you but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr.. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intruded yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr.. Keenan, say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that Mr.. Keenan is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you never lived in Lancaster,
so see that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defamations
to be published, that your attack OIL me must
be founded on envy and falschood as the public
know that advertise in this Borough in TIVE
newspapers to let every one in the Unitod
States know who am, what am, and where 7
am, SO that you are, to make the most of Won.
bad minded man. The principle cause. I be.
heve, OF your behaviour, is my sending Won bact


a pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted n


quarter of pound of the weight. done So to
prevent your doing so again--you, in an nsolen,
manner, told the woman that your wepbts were
as honest as mine. But this would not do vo,,r
son had to give hera pound of candles as she
pad you tor them. This is one ofthe causcs ~
your savage lying, and vndctve malice. ''' u
| February %. 1872 I 49,

little; the third year cut them off about io
inches from the ground, in March; the fourth
year cut them from two or three feet high
taking away all but one branch from each
vine, for tralings to make the new rows, or
for cuttings to set elsewhere. Some OF the
vines bore grapes the third year, on the
shoots which grew the second year, (as 1t IS
always on the last years. shoots, the grapes
are borne, after which these shoots, which
have borne, are taken away, and the shoots
Of the preceding year left to bear, by being
cut from three to four feet high, tying them
to a prop or stake. When the young clust-
ers appear, pinch off the shoot above the
second cluster, and also the buds or sprouts
which put out at the but-end Of the stem OF
the leaves. which sprouts would form limbs
or branches that would cucumber the clus-
t-rs, and rob them too much Of the benefit OF
the sun and air. and also draw away TOO
much ofthe sap of the vine from the grapes,
and thus prevent them from coming to per-
fection.


GATHERING.
cut the clusters Oft, and carry them TO
the press. The epoch OF maturity is about
the first of October mash them (the
grapes)wel. and then press them like Cider
&c. &c. &c.





EXPENSES.
I calculate it cost me seventy live dollars
per acre to plant and attend to the vines,
until they began the third year to bear.


QUANTITY.


In four acres, about one fourth bore grapes
the third year, and made about three bar
rels of wine; the fourth year made thirteen
barrels; tie mn gear M,rty-one barrels,
| (fifteen and half hogsheads.) But must
observe, that many of the vines were young,
as yook away many that were not OF a
good sort, and replaced them, and the first
vines were two years old, and in some places
three, before they were sufficiently long to
trail, and form the Intermediate rows; sc
that, in the fifth year, some were but two
and some three years old, of course not in a
bearing conditiop. ! think | NAV safely
say not more than half were i'll a bearing
conditions


PRICE.


We got for the first wine, four dollars
fer gallon. .dtferuards 7ee sold a. three
and gve are noqu selling al taro doIlars IN
gallon.


CUTTINGS.


The last season we sold l4,0O0, abou
four feet long. at thirty dollars per thousand
420 dollars.


Yours. &c.


THOS: EICHELBERGER.
VIM. LEE, Auditor, Washington.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMDR.

From the Philadelphia Palladium.
CULTIVATION OF THE VINE.
full articles.article:
From the, fhiiadelPnia fallauiu'n.


CULTIVATION OF THE VINE
The National Intelligencer of "Wednesday /
contains well written communication from
a Mr.. Album, on the culture of the Vine
AS we shall eventually make our own wines
in this country,-the sooner the better,-we
have thought it would be interesting to our
readers to learn how profitable this business
may be made by those possessing enter
prise, industry, and the resolution to conquer
their attachment to old habits


The writer commences with remarks on
the cultivation Of the vine in France, and
with sundry statements exhibiting the an
nual expense of cultivating an acre of vines
in various parts of Europe, the quantity OF
wine produced, and the nett produce per
acre. He remarks that four acres of vine
are sufficient in France to occupy one labor
err and thinks that an American laborcr
will perform twice the quantity that a
French peasant will. An acre of vines netts
in Provence, $40 IS; Guinenne, 3 IS; the
Lyonnais, 26 73; Nivornois, IS 10; in the
different departments of Burgundy, from 8
13 to % so; Sologne 6 27; Seine l8 36;
Champagne, 6 16 Hevouches Chaptal for
the accuracy of these statements.


"Ten acres of the vines i'll France pro-
duced ninety hogsheads of SO gallons each,
valued at 1854 e3; the expense of cutivat
ing those ten acres amounts to $3.50 7e; an
interest of ten per centum on those expenses
amounts to S35 81; and the indemnity
of from eight to ten per cent. for loss of
crops amounts to $50 SO, leaving nett prof
it on the 10 acres, OF Sl38 ID, or 13 81 for
each acre.


A small compensation, though double the
nett profit of an acre of corn or wheat in the
United States in ordinary times. In France
the acre of vine is considered more pro-
ductive than an acre of wheat.


Yhe article closes with the following Just
views of the profits of Vineyard, conduct
ed with skill and industry. One thing we
may observe that the culture of the vine
promises as great prosperity III Pennsy ylvania
as in Virginia.


1t appears to us, no sugar or cotton plan,
tc.tion, in their best and most hourishing pc
riods; no species of agriculture, in the best
soils, or horticulture in rich gardens in the
vicinity of large city markets. ever produced
Iuch profits as the vine would yield for a CEN
fury to come if properly cultivated in the U,
States.


The heavy impost on foreign wines, oper-
ates not only as a protecting duty, but as a
prodigious bounty.


If young proprietor, who has just come
60 his estate, in that beautiful section of our
country. would set seriously to work in
planting the vine, before he arrives at the
middle age of man, he would inevitably be-
come the richest planter in the state.


Of the old planter, we cannot expec,
much reformation, for


"Habits are stubborn things;


And when man is turned of forty,


The ruling PASSIONS grown SO naughty,


There's no clipping of its wings


He offers very satisfactory statement o
the cost of vineyard of ten acres, making
1t amount on the fifth year of its culture
Ithe epoch of its full bearing) to 2,o25 dol
lars. Then follows a statement of gros
produce-annual advances for cultivation
and nett products Of an American Vineyard
Of ten acres.


This, it must be remembered, is not
mere creature of pen, ink, and paper but il
substantially that made by Mr.. Eichelberge
Of York, in Pennsylvania, who has devot
ed much time to the consideration of this sub
ject


Produce of ten acres.


so hhds. $3.50 gals. at doll. S3,79o 0


Deduct,


Annual advances per acre.


as dollars $3.50


Ten per cent interest there


on, 95


len per cent indemnity on


gross produce for loss of


crops 378


653 0
Nett product of the 10 acres S3,l27 0
Or S312 20 per acre.


A result which, we trust, offers suffi
cient encouragement to every reasonabl
proprietor of the soil 10 commence the ereo

full articles.headline: YORK, Penn. June 4. 1924.
full articles.article:
York. Penn. June 4, 1924.
Dear Sir--Yours of 5th ult came safe to
hand, and my being somewhat unwell must
be an apology for my not replying sooner.
Twill now attempt it, and to your first ques-
fion:


SOIL.


Mine is slaty ridge. in a limestone
country, and presume there is limestone
under it.


PLANTING.


Iplanted my vines in rows, by digging a
french four feet long, and about nine inches
wide, and fifteen inches deep. In this plant
cd, at each end, two cuttings, about three
and half or four feet long, letting two buds
appear on each vine above ground, then l
filled up the trench, packing the ground
pretty tight; then, four feet from the end OF
this trench. dug another similar, and plant
ed 1t in the same way, and so OH until the
row was finished. BY this mode the vines
are two in place, and each two, four feet
from the next in the row. The next row
planted twelve feet from the first, in the
same way. The second and third years,
when the shoots were long enough, dug a
trench crossways, from each row, four feet
long, towards the opposite row, and laid
the branches or shoots from the first plant
ed rows, IN them, letting the ends of the
two vines be little above ground; by this
means two rows in the twelve feet interval
are formed, which makes all the rows four
feet apart.


PRUNING.


The first year none; the second year very

sold the two classes FOR, as you could not get
more shan 500 dollars for each class. where
then did the Cos dollars come from over the
price of the two classcs' so that one might tninK
you wronged Hope, or made sham sale OF the
lottery, with an intent to defraud the church,
All, Mr.. Billy, we have documents from Thomas
Hopes hand, which firmly prove that the
nett profits on the first class, after paying the
prizes, amc lnted to 1896 dollars; and that the
profits on the second class amounted to 4765 dol
lars. What an unfortunate business for you!-A
You say the third class was managed by Patrick
Higgins-the following will say to the contrary;


Statement of Patrick Higgins.


81 shall state, as one Of the four managers OF
the Lottery, sold by William Larkin, principal
manager and treasurer, who received the pro-
ceeds of the four classes of the Delaware Lotte-
nv, intended by the Legislature of this State for
the use and benefit of st. Peters Church IN TINS
Borough, that after the first and second class
